Given the current historically positive relational climate RE Israel and its Arab neighbors(1) I find it highly unlikely that Israel will jeopardize the goodwill it has fostered by instigating regional violence. While I think Hezbollah has an incentive to stir up tensions in the region,  given that it is largely externally funded by Iran and Syria(2), who are currently grappling with COVID and a recent civil war respectively, I think the organization presently lacks the operational funding to risk a heavy Israeli military response at present.  References 
1. Daoud, David, 2020. “Welcome to a Brand-New Middle East”. Foreign Policy. Retrieved from https://foreignpolicy.com/2020/09/30/israel-uae-bahrain-palestinians-peace/ 2. Levitt, Matthew, 2005. “Hezbollah Finances: Funding the Party of God”. The Washington Institute. Retrieved from https://www.washingtoninstitute.org/policy-analysis/view/hezbollah-finances-funding-the-party-of-god

UN News. Peace and Security (2020) stated that:
\
Talks begin to resolve disputed Lebanon-Israel maritime border
\
The UN Secretary-General has welcomed the launch of ground-breaking discussions on Wednesday, over the disputed maritime border between Lebanon and Israel in the eastern Mediterranean, following a framework agreement between the two nations at the beginning of the month.
\
The process to resolve the long-running dispute, which could lead to the development of what news reports suggest are potentially lucrative natural gas fields under the disputed area, is being facilitated by the UN and the United States.
+

To say that tensions in the Middle East are high, would be an understatement and disservice to everyone involved. I cannot think of a time when issues were not likened to a dumpster fire, not in my lifetime at least. The recent explosion in Beirut is the reason behind the current tensions.  According to Reuters, “Hezbollah leader Sayyed Hassan Nasrallah says that his group would wait for results of an investigation into the Beirut port explosion, but if it turns out to be an act of sabotage by Israel then it would “pay an equal price” (Bassam, 2020). Israel has denied any involvement in the Aug. 4 blast that killed 172 people, injured 6,000, damaged swathes of the city and left 300,000 homeless. Hezbollah themselves have a history of attacking civilian populations in lieu of a standing military. Due to the fact that the United States has designated Hezbollah a foreign terrorist organization and continues close ties with the number one state sponsor of terrorism, Iran—I am hesitant to take anything that comes from their group as gospel. In fact, I would be more inclined to distrust mostly anything being reported unless it is accompanied with cold, hard facts. With all this being said, I assess the following outcome percentage of 15% Yes, that there will be a lethal confrontation between the armed forces of Hezbollah and those of Israel.

It is likely that there will be some type of skirmish between Lebanon and Israel. It could only be a few gun shots, rockets or some random soldiers exchanging gunfire. They are neighboring nations with a long history of fighting with irreconcilable religious and cultural differences.   Both nations have interest in maintaining and patrolling their borders. Recently the maritime border has been in the spotlight as well. https://www.nytimes.com/2020/10/01/world/middleeast/lebanon-israel-talks-border-gas.html

The Confrontation between Hezbollah and Israeli forces have gone back and forth for some time now, with various depictions released in the media. The Jerusalem Post describe how the actual war is being fought through the media and propaganda (Jerusalem Post, 2020). This fight can be seen through Al Jazeera reports that showcase false victories from official Israeli media accounts (Al Jazeera, 2020). According to Israel, they were able to thwart an attack from Hezbollah, while Hezbollah completely denied the attack and it was just a way to create propaganda. These reports not only increase tension between the groups, but it also escalates the possibility of an actual attack. Although the attack did not happen, analysts suggest that the fighting is not over, especially as Hezbollah seeks revenge (Haaretz, 2020). One of the last notable encounters between the two groups was in August when Israel hits Hezbollah compound in Lebanon after a short exchange of fire (Washington Post, 2020). As the battle between Hezbollah and Israeli forces have resulted in fatalities in the past, neither sides are a stranger to combat, however, most of the focus seems to be on fighting with propaganda. My predictions are as follows: 
-20% Yes

Between 14 November 2020, will there be a lethal confrontation in Lebanon or Israel between the armed forces of Hezbollah and those of Israel?     
Tensions still remain high between Israel and Hezbollah. Most recently, Hezbollah was very candid with their intensions, “and it vowed to remain committed to fighting Israel, as the country is paralyzed by its worst economic and financial crisis” (Times of Israel, 2020). Hezbollah wants to present a unified and strong front, however there are higher priorities. Covid-19 has required all nations to pay close attention and focus on the virus, 
“tension between Hezbollah and Israel has risen in recent weeks, at the same time that the coronavirus swept through the region. While both sides are busy combating the pandemic, they are also preparing for the expected continuation of the conflict once the crisis is over, while maintaining the existing balance of deterrence between them” (Mizrahi and Schweitzer, 2020).
The conflict has not gone away, and tensions are still high. However, everything that has unfolded because of COVID-19 have caused a drastic change in direction. Both Israel and Hezbollah are working on building up their forces which acts as a means of deterrence. Hezbollah has been stockpiling missiles at a rapid rate, “most estimates puts the present number of Hezbollah missiles and rockets at over 100,000” (Iddon, 2020). Hezbollah, while fighting has been limited, has been able to still build their military force. 
	While most tactics have been described as deterrence and proxy wars, there have been some deadly attacks, “Israel had been bracing for retaliation from Hezbollah since the killing of one of its operatives in a strike in Syria last week that was attributed to Israel” (Kershner, 2020). While both sides blame each other for the hostile actions, “no casualties were reported by either side” (Kershner, 2020). There is a lot of tension but with COVID-19, the troops have been limited. In my opinion, there is an 87% chance that there is not a lethal confrontation in Lebanon or Israel. 
Mizrahi, O., and Schweitzer, Y. (2020, May 6). The Israel-Hezbollah Confrontation amidst the Coronavirus Crisis. INSS. Retrieved from: https://www.inss.org.il/publication/israel-hizbollah-and-the-coronavirus/
Agencies and TOI Staff. (2020, September 29). Defying Macron, Hezbollah says it will continue to fight Israel. The Times of Israel. Retrieved from:   https://www.timesofisrael.com/defying-macron-hezbollah-says-it-will-continue-to-fight-israel/
Iddon, P. (2020, Jun 27). In A Third Lebanon Warm Israel Will Have To Contend With Increasingly Lethal Hezbollah Missiles. Forbes. Retrieved from: https://www.forbes.com/sites/pauliddon/2020/06/27/in-a-third-lebanon-war-israel-will-have-to-contend-with-increasingly-lethal-hezbollah-missiles/#31e98c984b5e
Kershner, I. (2020, July 27). Israel Says It Thwarted a Hezbollah Raid at Lebanon Border. The New York Times. Retrieved from: https://www.nytimes.com/2020/07/27/world/middleeast/israel-hezbollah-lebanon-fighting.html
dropping with the passage of time.

I define a lethal confrontation as one that results in a military fatality and/or civilian casualty. The confrontations between Hezbollah and Israel are ongoing, reaching back nearly two decades. Both parties have been accused of bombings, air raids, and missile strikes. However, the last major attack in August resulted in no deaths. The Israeli Defense Forces (IDF) has recently updated their website with information regarding Hezbollah in Lebanon and in Syria. There are also a several Jewish and Arab holidays in the month of October which would lower the chances of a confrontation between the armed forces. 
With this in mind, I say that there is a 30% chance of a lethal confrontation in Lebanon or Israel between the armed forces of Hezbollah and those of Israel.

https://apnews.com/article/international-news-middle-east-lebanon-united-nations-3477c82de8554c2b26b98be9b9bcd096 https://www.idf.il/en/minisites/hezbollah/exposed-three-hezbollah-missile-sites-in-beirut/ https://www.dw.com/en/hezbollah/t-41508807 https://www.aljazeera.com/tag/hezbollah/ https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/8/4/israels-netanyahu-warns-hezbollah-after-syria-attack

Yes, I assess that there is a 56% chance that constant skirmishes along the border of Lebanon and Israel will result in further casualties among both military and civilian populations prior to 14 November 2020. On August 25, Israel carried out air attacks on Hezbollah observation posts in Lebanon. This came as a response to a security incident that occurred at the border. The activity was later identified as gunshots directed at IDF troops. Israel and Lebanon are still technically at war, and the United Nations force UNIFIL is tasked with monitoring the ceasefire. An incident a month earlier occurred when two drones packed with explosives targeted the group's stronghold in south Beirut. An additional confrontation unfolded when supposed Hezbollah fighters attempted to sneak across the border. On August 29th, Israeli tanks carried out strikes against Hamas posts in the Gaza Strip in response to the previous day’s launching of airborne incendiary devices into Israel, which sparked at least 23 fires in the south of the country. While not devastating, this attack against Israel was coordinated with a manifesto calling for a long-term campaign against their enemies by Hezbollah. 
	Public relations between the two parties have also evaporated due to the UAE and Israel's announcement to normalized relations, a decision which is seen by Lebanon as a serious threat. Hezbollah later condemned Bahrain’s move to normalize Israel ties on September 12. Hezbollah is the world’s most heavily armed non-state actor per the Center for Strategic and International Studies. They possess manpower capabilities which are estimated at 30,000 fighters with a reservist corps that could draw upon another 10,000 to 20,000 combatants. In addition, they possess extensive technology such as surface to air missiles. Israel’s military stands at roughly 169,500, including 102,500 conscripts; however, they are spears across a larger area and are forced to be more defensive. Thus, Hezbollah will continue to utilize similar patterns and tactics to instigate violence along the border.
	Hezbollah is facing a major internal crisis in the shape of government mismanagement and years of slow growth which has saddled Lebanon with one of the world’s highest public debt burdens. Protests have erupted spending several religious and cultural backgrounds. In August 2020, when an UN-backed tribunal found Salim Jamil Ayyash, a Hezbollah affiliate, guilty of the 2005 assassination of former Lebanese Prime Minister Rafiq Hariri. This further factor has placed Hezbollah in a position where their very survival as an organization may be dependent on regaining prestige through the use of violence. Therefore, the trend of violence will with a moderate degree of certainty result in the death of a member of one of these two sides prior to November 14th.

"Hezbollah, armed and backed by Iran, has more than 100,000 rockets and has been increasing its investments in drones and precision-guided missiles. Israel has also been increasing its investments in high-tech defence systems to counter the threat, including the famed 'iron dome' system that shoots down rockets, drones and other threats. To make forces more lethal on the battlefield Israel has invested in these kinds of drills to make infantry and tanks work more closely together. I think that there will be a lethal confrontation between the armed forces. There is currently a lot of bad blood between Lebanon and Israel.   The term lethal confrontation is a low bar.  As someone else pointed out, one has to define "lethal confrontation", does that mean all-out war or invasion from either party or just a cross boarder shooting or grenade attach that kills one person? There have been several recent attacks with no casualties reported, but lethal action is not overwhelmingly likely but probable. 
Seems there is always some tension and  form of fighting on the boarder, but no one is taking ownership of small attacks.  A small lethal confrontation is likely before mid-November as  both sides are assessing the other and building up for bigger attacks. The tensions will likely build into greater bloodshed.
I am about 55 % convinced that some form of lethal confrontation will occur between the two armed forces. The two nations seem to definitely be poised for conflict, but I believe the bomb in Lebanon in early August has given the Lebanese a lot more to worry about than Israel, as they are still reeling from that explosion.

Delphi Method led our train of thought on this one. Our initial estimate sat at low probability and rounded was 47.5% yes, it would be a lethal confrontation. Our research automatically showed us that our prediction was 100% right because there was a lethal confrontation. The Good Judgment post was posted August 14 and the “inevitable” attack that was promised happened on August 25, 2020. Additionally, a Hezbollah stronghold was hit with an explosion that caused both panic and left buildings damaged. It is believed to have belonged and originated with Israeli forces. This attack happened on September 22.  Our final prediction is at 100% yes.

We responded with fire, & our aircraft struck Hezbollah observation posts near the border,”. Tensions have been extremely high in late 2020 between Hezbollah and Israel. In July Israel killed Hezbollah’s commander in an airstrike. Hezbollah has already stated that they will avenge this death. Israel also took the strong initiative to strike Hezbollah targets after a bombing on Golem Heights was stopped. Israel is obviously not afraid to show their intolerants of any Hezbollah activity. Israel will not hesitate to launch any attack they see necessary to protect their people. On the other hand, both of these attacks were on Syrian soil. It will also be very dumb for Hezbollah to attack on Israel soil, but it has happened before. The more likely outcome is that Israel will directly cripple Hezbollah in Lebanon as a result of more violent actions toward Israely ideals. High tensions have already resulted in a skirmish on the Israely-Lebanon border when both sides exchanged fire and closed roads. Although no lives were lost on either side, this could very easily result in a bloody battle. The real question is, “Will Hezbollah make direct action to threaten Israel?” If this occurs, Israel will attempt to put down this threat immediately, which will result in casualties.

I predict there is a 35% chance that there will be a lethal confrontation between Hezbollah and Israel before 14 November. Netanyahu has stated that although both sides have political difficulties, “Israel doesn’t want a large-scale confrontation with Hezbollah at this time”. Furthermore, Israel and Hezbollah are aware of the consequences of a large lethal confrontation. Predictions reason that recent tensions could result in minor conflict, yet both sides will try to “limit” them. Blanford summarized that the consequences of a Third Lebanon War would result in “the greatest destruction and loss of life since the 1948 war, and Lebanon will be turned into a car park”. Although Hezbollah has the capability to invade Northern parts of Israel, they know the resulting war would destroy Lebanon, and likely Hezbollah with it. Because reports show that neither side is searching for Lethal conflict, I predict there is a 35% chance of such conflict occurring before 14 November.

I say this prediction because Israel launched an airstrike previously and Hezbollah stated that a counterattack was coming, that attack has yet to come. I predict a 70% chance of a lethal confrontation between Hezbollah and Israel prior to 14 November 2020, determined by observing current tensions and attack trends between the two groups. On 20 July 2020, a Hezbollah fighter was killed by an IDF airstrike, leading Hezbollah leader Hassan Nasrallah to vow revenge in the form of the deaths of Israeli soldiers. According to the IDF, since the 20 July airstrike, Hezbollah has attempted to cross the U.N established "Blue Line" border and has shot at Israeli soldiers, increasing tensions between the belligerents. Hezbollah's "equation of deterrence" policy makes it likely that more retaliatory attacks will occur, likely resulting in Israeli casualties. Even if deaths do not occur for Israel, they will likely respond with airstrikes. This assertion is based on how Israel has responded to recent Hezbollah incursions; shots fired at Israeli soldiers in August lead to multiple airstrikes against Hezbollah positions. Hezbollah's desire for revenge couples with Israeli responses leads me to predict a 70% of a lethal confrontation before 14 November. Resources
Gross, Judah Ari. "After 58 Days Bracing For Hezbollah Attack, IDF Shows No Sign Of Easing Up". Timesofisrael.Com, 2020, https://www.timesofisrael.com/after-58-days-bracing-for-hezbollah-attack-idf-shows-no-sign-of-easing-up/. Accessed 24 Sept 2020. Near the end of August, a single isolated incident occurred between the two forces on the Lebanon border, but this resulted in zero casualties. By definition, this was a confrontation but not a lethal one. Since then, there have been no other incidents and surprisingly Israel is set to hold mediated talks with Lebanon over their maritime border disputes. There is no certainty that these talks will result in an agreement between the two countries, but it is a hopeful step in the right direction that for now points towards a period of peace. Given the trajectory of current events towards mediation, coupled with their lack of diplomatic relations and current state of war, the chance for a lethal confrontation to break out is about even at this time. The Situation in Lebanon is very shaky and unknown, with two forces (Israel and Hezbollah) known to be aggressive and vengeful. Efforts to establish a functioning government in Lebanon have not been successful, and the world is now watching. With this instability, border skirmishes are possible, and small mistakes by soldiers on the ground can cause large conflicts. Lebanon is one of the most corrupt governments in the world, and its people have been in protest since the blast; the Hezbollah may see this as an opportunity to wage more covert terrorist attacks against Israel and gain more control in the Lebanon Parliament in which they control thirteen seats. I would reduce 3 percent of my forecast every day until November 14th.

Overall, Israel’s and Hezbollah's relationship is built upon mutual deterrence. Both sides have proclaimed multiple threats and have taken many threatening actions against one another. Israel has launched dozens of preemptive drone strikes on Irainian/Hezbollah targets in Syria. Then along the border of Lebanon, there is a vast amount of Israeli forces stationed in order to prevent any further attack from Hezbollah militants. Along this border Israel has deterred a number of small attacks from Hezbollah forces, but has decided to not pursue them into Lebanon. All of these actions from Israel are strictly preemptive and are based on Israel’s desire to only protect its people and interests. In all, Israel does not want to escalate the conflict with Hezbollah in order to avoid unnecessary conflict. Presently, Hezbollah has been reluctant in escalating the conflict due to their fear of inferiority to the Israeli military and their incapability to launch a large scale attack. In addition, the US has placed sanctions on Libanese forums and leaders that have ties to Hezbollah. To summarize, both sides have high tension between each other and it is very likely that a lethal confrontation will occur. Nevertheless, Israel is at somewhat of a stand still, and Hezbollah forces do not currently have the means to cause any paramount harm to the Israeli military.

Starting from a quantitative perspective, according to ACLED there were very few to no casualties between Hezbollah and Israel forces in the past say 10 years, although escalations of a similar sort occurred. On the other hand, "one fatality" is a very low - almost accidental - threshold, this is a difficult question.  What seems to be a good contextual base is the concept of "balance of deterrence", in which neither side wants an open confrontation in the view of possible repercussions, because the enemy is geared over time to inflict the greatest damage on my army in case I attack. Together with some UN presence, this seems like a fairly credible answer to the question of how is it that Israel and Lebanon are at war since 2006 with virtually no casualties on the border since then. You can find commentators that advance this argument in this specific case, arguing the incentive on either side to escalate is low (though miscalculated escalation can never be ruled out in such a setting).  But then there are the recent tensions and the low threshold of one fatality on either side. They exchange fire, Israel attacked observation posts, killed a Hezbollah soldier in Syria - the last point being the most important, as Hezbollah promised a revenge to deter Israel. And if confirmed that more Hezbollah fighters were killed in another attack today in Syria, the organization may be slowly put under more pressure to retaliate in kind if it's not to lose face. However, it seems quite important to note that Hezbollah leadership expressly refused to engage Israel on the Israel-Lebanon border, and that it stated it's "in no rush" to avenge the mujahedeen by killing Israeli soldiers. Overall, the situation is very untransparent and one fatality can never be ruled out (even though larger escalation probably could), but it seems that more indications exist that the Israeli-Lebanese border will not be the main theater where this confrontation shapes out.  Considering this and the fact that no death since 2006 on this border occurred despite recurrent exchanges of fire and air attacks (an incident nearly every year), my forecast will lean to a very uneasy "no". I will bet both sides have it under enough control (after so many years of a quite active mutual deterrence) and are sufficiently short of interests to escalate that they will avoid fatalities. Hopefully, Nasrallah will be satisfied with material damage like downing another drone, or rather that the clashes happen elsewhere (Syria), as he insinuated could be the case. 42%

Recent tensions, but in everyone's interest to keep things calm for a bit.

I think it possible but not likely that a lethal confrontation will occur on Lebanese or Israeli soil before 14 Nov 2020 (although a lethal confrontation between Hezbollah and Israel in Syria is possible and Hezbollah has stated intent to avenge any Israeli killing of Hezbollah forces in Syria). Tensions are escalating (source: https://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2020/08/israel-lebanon-border-tank.html), but I think ultimately neither government wants a lethal confrontation that could escalate right now because they've got a lot else going on. Israel may be nearing a military confrontation with Hamas before the summer fighting season ends and is unlikely to want to fight on two fronts (esp. amid a pandemic). Israel lodges protest with UN against Hezbollah border breach (4:20 pm)
https://www.timesofisrael.com/liveblog-august-17-2020/ "Israel’s UN Ambassador Gilad Erdan files a formal complaint with the United Nations Security Council over what Israel says was a failed attack by the Hezbollah terror group on Israeli troops along the Lebanese border. In his complaint, Erdan says the Hezbollah cell was armed with a .50-caliber sniper rifle, which was recovered at the scene, along with military fatigues. According to the IDF, on July 27, a cell of three Hezbollah operatives entered the area of Mount Dov, also known as Shebaa Farms, a contested area along the border under Israeli control. The Israel Defense Forces monitored the cell as it crossed the border into Israeli territory, at which point troops on the ground, as well as aircraft, opened fire at the suspected operatives, driving them back into Lebanese territory, apparently unharmed. Erdan includes a map that he says shows the route of the cell, up a rocky, tree-covered hill, eventually reaching a few dozen meters inside Israeli territory, roughly 300 meters from the IDF’s Gladiola outpost."
Via ACLED data - Monthly probability of such an event over the past twenty years is 2%.
Backing off a bit, lethal is a high bar to cross.

It may happen, some incidents occurred in the last few months and one of these may be lethal. I feel it’s a rare event though in the course of the year, and Lebanon is busy otherwise. This might not be a reason though...

The average gap between Hezbollah attacks is 651.3 days. Given that there are 365 days in one year there is a 56 percent chance of an attack in any given year. The question however, specifically mentions a confrontation between Hezbollah and Israeli military forces. Of the attacks referenced in the Stanford CISAC (which is not a comprehensive list) only 2 explicitly mention the Israeli military. If there is an attack, there is a 10 percent historical chance that it will directly involve some kind of Israeli military presence leaving us with a base rate of 5 percent approximately. [1] However, we are also above average in terms of time between attacks. The last attack occurred about 800 days ago.  it is probably worth pushing this base rate up to say, for instance, 9 percent.  Hezbollah has insisted they will retaliate if Israel is found to have had any involvement in the Beirut bombing and the FBI is said to be consulting on the investigation. [2][3] While it’s impossible to say what the FBI will find, we can apply some historical context to get a rough idea of the probabilities we’re talking about here. A Department of Justice report from 2000 claimed that about 8 percent of all explosive incidents in the US have some kind of criminal intent. [4] Let’s triple that for the Middle East which brings us to 24 percent. Criminal intent doesn’t necessarily lead us to the conclusion that Israel perpetrated the bombing. Most of their targeted killings in the past decade have involved missile or bomb strikes of relative precision rather than some kind of mass casualty event. [5] At this point while tensions are certainly high, it doesn’t seem likely that Israel will be found to have done anything untoward. It doesn’t really fit their MO or match up with FBI stats. Even if Hezbollah was to make good on their threat in the event that something is uncovered, their own history shows they would rather attack civilian or political targets than military ones.  To put a finer point on a probability we could take the 5 percent base rate of Hezbollah attacks on Israeli targets, double it due to increased tension and add a couple extra points envisioning some kind of scenario where Hezbollah rebukes the US-led findings as inadequate and attacks. All of this in view of the fact that we have only 92 days until the question deadline which is also coincidentally the shortest period between Hezbollah attacks, occuring twice in twenty incidents. Reports of informal rules of engagement - that ISR has started warning prior to attacking Hezbollah infrastructure, to avoid killing any HVTs and provoking a wider conflict.  I suggest 30% because the basis of these informal ROEs (a) might be overstated and (b) don’t preclude inadvertent deaths. Not that we’d really be able to know the difference between an intentional and unintentional death. Also recent diplomatic recognition by UAE and possibly others following suit could increase pressure on Hezbollah to provoke ISR.

Hezbollah, as guardians of the destroyed Beirut port will be suffering, but they still a strong force (and welfare  givers) within the country and willing to support their backers.

This is probably a model question for one of those cognitive biases where you think "doesn't this happen all the time, go for twice the consensus or 50%" - and then go back and find that it's actually <50% likely in a given year, far less so in 3 months. Therefore, I like to be lower than the crowd on this one until war is declared, but not by too much - the tank incident referenced in the question demonstrates that one single combatant death on either side is not just a tail risk. Assassinations would count, civilian deaths won't.
These are trying times for most populations. Miscalculations are more likely when individuals are under stress. Lebanon is in tatters with no clear leadership an ideal time for a strongman to emerge.
While tensions are still running high between the two nations, that epic blast combined with an economic freefall has led to massive civil unrest. Right now, Lebanon has its hands full.
